results.title: Editing
results.creator_credit: Bruce A. Block, Tim Barr and AIMS Instructional Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Discusses the processes of film editing from the preparation of the work print to the completion of a finished, edited film. Explains the processes of setting up the editing bench, rewinding, using the moviescope, splicing, breaking-down the work print, marking, adding dialogue and using the moviola.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce A. Block, Tim Barr and AIMS Instructional Media

results.title: Camera
results.creator_credit: Bruce A. Block, Tim Barr and Charles Cahill and Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Uses interviews with cinematographers including Lazlo Kovacs, Lee Garmes and James Crabe to explain the major points of motion picture photography and cameras. Defines and explains many techniques including dolly shots, lenses, camera movement, film speeds and camera focus.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce A. Block, Tim Barr and Charles Cahill and Associates

results.title: Acting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Shows a stage actor during audition and his transition to a motion picture actor. Well known actors including Helen Hayes, Vincent Price, Henry Fonda, Jim Backus, Jean Stapleton, Jeff Corey, Royal Dano, Mariette Hartley, Janet McLachlan and Paul Newman appear and discuss problem areas that a film actor must deal with.

results.title: Film making
results.brief_description: Films designed for school orientated learning have brought a new impact and excitement to learning previously unavailable in the classroom. In this investigation, the actual production of such a film is followed from beginning to finished product. It goes from covering the idea, script, costing, cameraman, director, crew, actors, titles, lettering, animation, editing, narration and music.
results.description: Films designed for school orientated learning have brought a new impact and excitement to learning previously unavailable in the classroom. results.title: A Film for Discussion
results.creator_credit: Jeni Thornley, Martha Ansara and Sydney Women's Film Group
results.brief_description:
The Sydney Women’s Film Group was formed in 1971 by a small group of feminists who were troubled by the lack of options for women filmmakers in Australia, and appalled by the depiction of women in the media. The group produced and distributed films, held screenings and discussions, ran production workshops for women, and lobbied for women’s access to film funding and education. “Our aim was to further the spread of our revolutionary ideas through the visual media” (Jeni Thornley). Many of Australia’s women filmmakers owe their inspiration or start to this seminal group’s activities.

‘A Film for Discussion’ is the group’s first production, and is possibly the first feminist film made in Australia. The juxtaposition of experimental and realist sequences in the depiction of a ‘day in the life’ of an ordinary young woman, parallels the ‘personal is political’ ethos of 1970s feminism.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeni Thornley, Martha Ansara and Sydney Women’s Film Group

results.title: Film firsts. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: Paul Killiam, Saul J. Turell and Gregstan Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
This film spotlights the remarkable achievements of a quartet of great film pioneers, Edwin S.Porter, Georges Melies, Thomas H.Ince, and D.W.Griffith, who in a few years prior to 1914 brought imagination, drama, technical innovations and photographic trickery to the screen. Illustrated by excerpts from the films.

results.title: Film firsts. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: Paul Killiam, Saul J. Turell and Gregstan Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
Traces the techniques and situations used by film makers during the early years of experimentation with the film medium. In its first two decades the industry tried almost all of the techniques and situations which were to be developed or reintroduced later. Specific names, dates, and excerpts from early films illustrate the work of innovators in techniques, equipment, stories, themes, roles and industry operation. Developments include the first use of synchronized sound; tracking with movie cameras; animation; models; props, and camera trickery for special effects, and underwater photography.

results.title: Film exercise
results.creator_credit: Rodney Charters and University of Auckland. School of Fine Arts
results.brief_description: This first film by a young New Zealand art student uses the motorcycle as a sex symbol in the lives of the “beat” generation…a girl’s infatuation with a motorcycle and its rider. This film was made as a design project at the School of Fine Arts, University of Auckland, and makes interesting use of various film techniques.
